en-us.learning_promise:
**Learning Promise**
In this unit, your students will create clearly named variables and lists representing different data types, and perform basic math operations on their values. They'll learn how to make cloud data useful and reliable, improve their programs to refine a solution, and design projects that combine hardware and software components to collect and exchange data.

lessons.lesson_description: Synchronize motor movements of a "break dancer" to keep in rhythm with light and beats.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Sitting for a long time? Remember to get up and move. Build a “Break Dancer” to remind you to take breaks and stay active. Dance along to your favorite music all throughout the day!

text.content:
How much time do you spend sitting down? Think about the time you spend in class, on the computer, watching TV, or playing video games.

Do you think it’s important to stand and take regular breaks? Why?

It’ll dance to the beat and remind you to get up and move. 

If you have time, build your own design.

text.content:
Play this program.

Change the timing to make the dancer’s legs move 10 times in sync with the light.

For example, have the legs start to move when the number 1 is light up on the Hub.
Now, use what you’ve just learned and sync the dancer’s arms with the light.

Don't forget to change the Ports for the arms motor.

It could look something like this:

Can you keep everything in sync?

text.content:
Now that everything’s in sync, program your dancer to remind you to take breaks every 60 seconds.

Don’t forget to get up and dance!
There are many ways to take a break but it’s recommended that you take a time-out every 75-90 minutes. It’ll help you focus more during the day.

Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

Dance. Life hack. A perfect match!

lessons.title: SPIKE Break Dance

lessons.lesson_description: Use variables to count the number of sit-ups and calories burned during a workout.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: How many sit-ups can you do? Sometimes you might have a partner to count for you, but it gets harder to keep track when you're sweating on your own.  Let’s create a life hack to count your reps!

step.title: Can you keep count while exercising?

text.content:
When athletes train, they normally do reps, a set, or a routine. 

Can you think of an example of each of these exercise terms?

Leo, your personal trainer, will help you count your sit-ups.

If you have time, build your own design.

text.content: You should see that Leo does some sit-ups by himself.
Now, use a variable to add a counting element to this program.

Insert the “set sit-ups” block at the beginning of the  programming stack to define the value you’ll start counting from.

Add a “change sit-ups by 1” block when Leo has completed one sit-up.

Add the “reporter” block to the light block to visualize the content of your variable.

It could look something like this:

step.title: Add a second variable to count calorie burn.

text.content:
The calories will increase by 3 for each group of 5 sit-ups. 

Display calorie burn on the Programming Canvas.
You’ll need to create another variable that will count calories burned.

Use more bricks or change your program to give your trainer more personality.

Record a video of a workout.

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

... 6, 7, 8, 9, 10… keep going, you’ve got this!

lessons.title: SPIKE Repeat 5 Times

lessons.lesson_description: Create a way of displaying a weather forecast using qualitative cloud data.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Performing qualitative operations using cloud data
lessons.student_worksheet_description: How many days will it rain or shine this week? Let’s create a life hack that will show you! Because really, who wants to waste time watching the weather report?

step.title: What will the weather be like today?

text.content:
Weather forecasts use data to make predictions. 

How reliable do you think this data is?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Life Hacks Rain or Shine

text.content:
Let's see how good it is at predicting today's weather!

If you have time, build your own design.

step.title: Check the conditions: is it sunny?

comments.comment:
This stack will place your weathercaster in position.
Enter the name of your city here!
This stack will make your weathercaster react only if it’s sunny in the location you’ve set.

text.content:
Let's see!

Set the location to your city and see what happens if it’s sunny.
Check out the help section to find out more about how to use the Weather Blocks.

step.title: What’s the forecast for the next 5 hours?

text.content:
Create a program so the Weathercaster can describe the weather for the next 5 hours.

Record the Weathercaster’s prediction in a table.

You’ll have to find ways to communicate if it’s: 
* Sunny
* Cloudy
* Foggy
* Snowy
* Rainy
* Partly cloudy

Here’s one way to program this:

step.title: Check the forecast in other cities.

text.content:
Record the forecast for at least 2 other cities.

During the next 5 hours, record the actual weather in your table and compare the forecast data with the actual data.
Use weather websites or apps to get the current weather.

Take a moment to evaluate yourself. 

Congratulations… you’ve just life hacked the forecast!

lessons.title: SPIKE Rain Or Shine

lessons.lesson_description: Create a way to display wind speed using quantitative cloud data.
lessons.lesson_sub_title: Performing quantitative operations using cloud data
lessons.student_worksheet_description: How can you measure the speed of something you can’t see? And wait, how is wind speed measured anyway? Well, you can display that data on your desk. Let’s create a life hack that will tell you if you can or can’t do a certain activity on windy days.

text.content:
How can you measure the speed of something you can’t see?

How is wind speed measured?

It’ll show you the speed of the wind and tell you if it’s safe to fly a drone or a kite, play volleyball, or have a party outside.

If you have time, build your own design.

text.content: Enter the name of a city and play the program to see what happens.
The Wind Indicator will point to the same location even if the wind speed in your chosen location is different for the next 24 hours.

step.title: Make the Wind Indicator show you the wind speed.

text.content:
Divide the scale into 2 parts:
* If it’s windy, move to yellow
* else, move to blue

For this first part, you could define that:
* “Not windy” is below 5.5 m/s
* “Windy” is above 5.5 m/s

step.title: Make your Wind Indicator more precise.

text.content: Now extend your program to increase the precision of your scale by dividing it into 4 parts.

Let the Beaufort scale inspire you.
* Blue : Beaufort Scale 1-3 (1 to 12 mph or 0.5 - 5.5 m/s), light to gentle breeze
* Green: Beaufort Scale 4-6 (13 to 31 mph or 5.5 - 13.8 m/s), moderate to fresh breeze
* Yellow: Beaufort Scale 7-9 (31 to 54 mph or 13.8 - 24.4 m/s), strong wind to very strong wind
* Red: Beaufort Scale 10-12 (55 to greater than 73 mph or 24.4 - 32.7 m/s), storm to hurricane
Add a function to display wind direction.
You can use sounds or the Display, but can you be more creative?

Think about what you did well and how you could improve for next time.

Now you can see the wind!

lessons.title: SPIKE Wind Speed

lessons.lesson_description: Use live forecast data to decide whether tomato plants will need to be watered this week.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Will you water your plants this week? Will they thrive? Will they wilt? Will they drown? Let’s create a life hack to tell you exactly how much water your plants need to blossom.

text.content:
You might already know that it’s important to water the garden once in a while. Vegetables need a certain amount of water per week in order to grow.

How much water is enough and how much is too much?
Can you find out how much water your favorite vegetable needs in order to grow?

Build this Tomato-Meter.
It’ll tell you whether you need to water your tomato plants.

If you have time, build your own design.

step.title: Try your meter before calibrating it.

text.content:
To check that everything works:

1. Play the program to move the needle from left to right.
2. Look on the Hub to find out how many degrees of motor rotation it takes to go from one end of the scale to the other.

1. The number may vary slightly between models. Your Hub should display a value between 450 and 600 degrees.
2. You can use the Absolute Value Block to make sure that the degrees of motor rotation is a positive value.

step.title: Show how much rain there will be today.

text.content:
Insert a sheet of paper that’s been pre-printed with the tomato scale.

For each hour of the day, find a way to move the needle in proportion to the amount of rain that should’ve fallen.

The length of the scale on the paper is d=90 mm. To indicate that it has rained 1 mm, you should rotate the motor like this:

60 mm of rain --> 450 ° 

1 mm --**7.5 °**

So your program could look like this:

step.title: Do you need to water the garden?

text.content:
Extend your program to cover the whole week (7 days) and evaluate whether your tomato garden will get enough rain.

Tomatoes need about 50 mm of rain per week to grow successfully.

What? You don't like tomatoes ?

Change the scale to display the temperature for the next 5 days and evaluate if there’s anything else you can plant.

Seeds only grow when the temperature is right for them to germinate.

Find out which seeds can germinate at which temperatures.

What did you do well? Is there something you could’ve done better?

Now you can use this life hack to grow your love of veggies!

lessons.title: SPIKE Veggie Love

lessons.lesson_description: Record multiple values at the same time in an array (list), and compare values.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: You’ve exercised your body. Now it’s time to exercise your brain. You’ll have to be lightning fast to find the right sequence!  Let’s create a life hack that’ll make your brain sharp as a tack!

step.title: Are you good at logical games?

text.content: Name some ways that playing games can help maintain and improve your memory.

Meet the Game Master. It’ll read the colors of the candy stick bricks you feed into it!

If you have time, build your own design.

comments.comment: Press the Left Button on the Hub. This will make the Game Master eat the candy stick, then read and record its sequence of colors in the list called "Candy1.”

This stack will light up the position of the red brick on the candy stick. 

If you place the red brick at the bottom of your candy stick, the Game Master will detect it and congratulate you.

text.content:
Play this program. It’ll use an array to detect the position of the red brick in the first candy stick. 

Red is given the number value 9.

An array is like a one-column table with multiple rows.


Your Game Master will ‘eat’ the candy stick and then spit it out. Then the position of the red brick will be displayed on the Light Matrix.

If you place the red brick at the bottom of your candy stick, the Game Master will detect it and congratulate you.

* Assemble player 2’s candy stick (now you should have 2 different candy sticks).
* Program the Game Master to display the red brick’s position on the Light Matrix.
* Use one array for each candy stick in your program.
The Game Master should display the position of the red brick when the right button of the Hub is pressed.

step.title: Is it in the same position?

text.content:
Shuffle the 2 candy sticks.

Create a program that’ll play a sound if the red bricks are in the same position in each of the stacks of bricks.

Explore different ways to use “IF ELSE” conditional statements.

For example:

text.content:
Shuffle both candy sticks again.

Create a program that’ll tell you when the position of both candy stick bricks match.

Check the hint for the rules of the game.

Here are the rules:
* Player 1 feeds a candy stick to the Game Master, who records the sequence of colors in an array.
* Player 2 feeds another candy stick to Game Master, who records the sequence of colors in a second array.
* The program compares the 2 arrays and lights up an LED on a row to indicate where the colors of 2 bricks match. 
* Player 2 can reorder their bricks again to try and match the order of player 1’s bricks.

Check out these programs for inspiration:

Wow! that was a mind-blowing life hack!

lessons.title: SPIKE Brain Game

lessons.lesson_description: Design, build, and program a training coach to improve the process of mastering something.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Alright, let’s go! There’s only one way to meet your goals, and that’s to practice, practice, and then practice some more! Let’s create a life hack that will help you run faster, play beautiful music, or make awesome art!

step.title: Want to become an expert at something?

text.content:
Data can help improve your skills.

What does it take to reach the ultimate level?

step.title: Describe 2 activities you’d like to be good at.

text.content:
What type of training would you need?

How could you use data in your training program?

Think about a hobby or sport you do:
* Playing a musical instrument
* Dancing
* Knocking it out of the park on the baseball diamond
* Something else?

step.title: Design a coach for your chosen activity.

text.content: Build something to help you practice.
Visit the building instructions page for inspiration.

Test your solutions as many times as possible.

Use a fair testing method to compare them.

step.title: Prepare to share your training program.

text.content: Put together a demo and present it to your class.

Describe your trainer and how you’ve used data.

Talk about what your trainer is good at (or not so good at).

Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

**Well done! Now keep on hacking your life.**

lessons.title: SPIKE The Coach

en-us.title: SPIKE Life Hacks
en-us.unit_plan_description: Is there anything in your life that could benefit from a hack? What if that hack could help you see data? Or train your body, plan your free time, sharpen your mind... anything! Just hack it!
